node.title: A Nourishing Filipino-Inspired Soup for Fall
node.alt: Angela Dimayuga, left, and Ligaya Mishan, at Dimayuga’s Brooklyn home.
node.description: To celebrate the publication of ‘Filipinx,’ their new cookbook, the chef Angela Dimayuga and the writer Ligaya Mishan made nilaga.
node.content: ["The chef Angela Dimayuga grew up in San Jose, Calif., the fifth of six children in a Filipino American family, and still remembers the slowly simmering soups and stews that seemed to be constantly bubbling away in the kitchen of her childhood home. Because both of her parents worked \u2014 her mother as an administrator for IBM and Intel, her father as a manager at McDonald\u2019s \u2014 her mother would often cook a week\u2019s worth of food at once. One of her standbys was nilaga, a simple yet flavorful soup of slow-braised beef shanks, bone marrow and earthy vegetables. \u201cNilaga was something we had on regular rotation because it\u2019s nourishing and could feed a lot of us,\u201d says Dimayuga, 36, who, until recently, was the creative director of food and culture for the Standard hotels. \u201cIt\u2019s an easy dish to make, since it\u2019s all passive cooking: You throw the meat in with some water.\u201d Come dinnertime, the family would gather around the huge pots, ladling steaming broth, marrow bones and fragrant rice into their bowls before crowding together to eat.", "One can almost hear the household\u2019s mealtime din \u00ad\u00adin the pages of \u201cFilipinx: Heritage Recipes From the Diaspora,\u201d the new cookbook Dimayuga wrote with Ligaya Mishan, a writer at large for T, which comes out Nov. 2. It features roughly 100 recipes capturing the lively, communal spirit of the Filipino table \u2014 from those for rich stews and crunchy merienda (or snacks) to bracing condiments and acid-hued sweets \u2014 and paying tribute to the archipelago\u2019s hodgepodge of culinary influences: China, Japan, Spain, America, to name only a few.", "Dimayuga first conceived of the cookbook while working as the executive chef at the New York outpost of the San Francisco-based Mission Chinese Food. She began weaving Filipino ingredients and flavors \u2014 sour notes inspired by sinigang, a usually tamarind-based stew, for example \u2014 into the restaurant\u2019s eclectically Pan-Asian dishes, and was thrilled to discover a fan base for her home cuisine. Around the same time, she inherited a trove of family recipes punctiliously compiled by her mother, and when she adapted a handful of them in the Times, the reception was more enthusiastic than she could have expected. \u201cI heard people from around the world say they were so happy to find out the name of a dish that they had through their Filipino nanny, or that their military bunkmate showed them,\u201d says Dimayuga.", "The authors were intent on showcasing the diversity of the Filipino diaspora, which spans more than 100 countries, including Saudi Arabia, Italy and Australia. They invited people of Filipino descent to offer their perspectives on modern identity: The novelist Jessica Hagedorn discusses how she had to fight for representation in the literary world; the model and transgender activist Geena Rocero notes that Tagalog was a gender-neutral language before colonization smuggled in masculine-feminine binaries.", "Researching Filipino history and cuisine also allowed both Dimayuga and Mishan to connect to their families in deeper ways. \u201cIt became this project around our own curiosity of self,\u201d says Dimayuga, who came to empathize more deeply with her parents\u2019 experience of leaving their homeland \u2014 they emigrated from the Philippines in 1976 \u2014 while at the same time inviting them more fully into her life as a queer person. Mishan, who grew up in Honolulu, the daughter of a Filipino mother and an English father, ate Filipino food only occasionally as a child; \u201cIt wasn\u2019t a big presence in my life,\u201d she says. Writing the book and delving into her heritage \u201cbrought me very close to my mom for the first time in a long time because I was constantly consulting her, trying to learn. I was also consulting all of my Filipino friends. I felt like I had this wonderful sense of the barkada, which is the term for your friend group in Tagalog.\u201d", "Dimayuga and Mishan had planned to cook, recipe-test and write together, but the pandemic intervened. And so, in a sad irony, a book celebrating the sense of community that food can foster took shape with all of its collaborators isolated from one another, convening over the virtual table of Zoom. That is, until one unseasonably warm day in October, when the authors reunited at Dimayuga\u2019s Brooklyn apartment to toast the upcoming release of \u201cFilipinx\u201d over a meal of lumpia, rice coffee and the aforementioned nilaga, the first recipe they worked on for the book. It\u2019s a dish reminiscent of the French pot-au-feu \u2014 the classically trained Dimayuga nods to that here with the inclusion of turnips and leeks \u2014 with one difference being the addition of fish sauce and its telltale umami, which brings depth to the sweetness of the simmered vegetables. \u201cBecause nilaga was such a constant for me,\u201d she says, \u201cit\u2019s one that I crave all the time.\u201d", "Angela Dimayuga\u2019s Nilaga", "Ingredients:", "1. Fill a large pot with 2\u00bd quarts water. Salt and pepper the beef shanks and add them to the pot, along with the bay leaves. Cover and bring to a boil, then reduce the heat so that the liquid ripples without bubbling. Keep the lid on the pot. For the first 10 minutes of simmering, periodically lift the lid to check on the stock and skim off any foam that rises to the surface. Continue to simmer, skimming occasionally, for about 2 hours.", "2. Break apart the meat by prodding it with a spoon; it should fall off the bone. Do not discard the bones, as the marrow will continue to melt into the broth. Season the broth with the fish sauce and 1 tablespoon kosher salt (or to taste), and check the texture: If the broth is too thick and syrupy, add a little water to loosen. Then add the onion, potatoes, turnips, garlic and garbanzo beans and simmer for 20 minutes, or until the vegetables begin to soften. If using marrow bone medallions, add them to the broth now. (If your pot isn\u2019t big enough to hold all the medallions, cook them in a separate, smaller pot with a ladling of the nilaga broth.) Add the leek and cabbage and let simmer for another 15 minutes.", "3. To serve, ladle the stew over warm rice, and be sure to give each bowl at least one piece of beef, potato, turnip, cabbage, a few garbanzo beans and a finish of coarsely ground pepper \u2014 plus, for special occasions, a bone medallion, for each diner to scoop out the buttery marrow."]
